column4: Alright, I am at my wits end. How can I mount an hfs+ file system read-write? I was just doing it a few hours ago with libhfsp but now that isn't working for some reason. Does anyone have a stable solution?
disable journaling in OS X - use disk utility

I'm in ubuntu, and I dont' have OS X. I just need to mount this external HDD that happens to be formatted hfsplus. I JUST had it working, and I'm doing the exact same commands and it isn't going for some reason.
dunno - if it's formatted w/journaling, you probably need OS X to disable it
I had it working, I had just installed libhfsp0 and libhfsp-dev, but then I unmounted and suspended and now it isn't working
may be one of those "reboot, unplug, and try again" issues...
the "wits end" part is the me doing that about ten times
with staggered uninstalling and purging of those libraries and reinstalling them
changed anything with your configuration since you were able to do it?
Also, you may try using the live CD, in case something is borked up with your install's hfsplus support
no, nothing, hell, my mtab file even says rw on it
I've also uninstalled and intalled all of the hfs support packages again and again
I dunno, other than the possibility that journaling somehow became enabled on said disk at some point in time - or your install is somehow mysteriously borked up
This was literally in the space of an hour, where I was working on the drive, unmounted, suspended my laptop, and then tried to remount and it failed
dunno what's going on, HFS+ can be finicky
damn right. I hate wrestling with it, I've never gotten it completely down
try the live CD just to try and get it going - and try using it on a Mac (if you can find one) to check the journaling setting
there can't be journaling on it, I was JUST using it and it hadn't been plugged into anything except ubuntu
OK, I'm guessing the filesystem somehow got corrupted
filesystem is fine, I can see all of the data on there, its just mounted read-only
unfortunately, only Mac OS X has HFS+ disk repair tools
I've heard of things like this happening on HFS+ before, and often the only solution is to run Disk utility on a Mac - even if the problem developed when using Linux
sh*t, alright. Will my data be there?
Should be
